comments.commentBody: If you think you will find significant amounts of these micro-nutrients in any oil, even unrefined coconut, you are sorely mistaken.  Get them in other foods.  It's like the fascination with Himalayan Sea Salt.  You want (pick a mineral)?  Eat some food.

That's a broad, inaccurate statement. If someone has fat digestibility issues, they already know about it.

The MCT's that are high in coconut oils, and are the backbone of the Bulletproof oil, don't even use the liver.

The muslims are absent from the fight against radical Islam because core tenants
of the Islamic faith support violent action against non-believers.
There are no peace loving Islamic states. Every single country dominated by Islam
discriminates against non-believers. All Islamic states have laws that discriminate against women in ways that are not compatible with Western culture.
One of the foundational beliefs of Islam is that Islam and the state must be one to insure that Islamic law and the teachings of the Quran guide the culture of the Islamic state. Islamic state cultures and laws are incompatible with Western beliefs and there is no reason for Western European states to tolerate Islamic jihadist preaching.

I’ve also wondered since 9-11 why Muslims have not taken any forceful or definitive action against Islamic terrorism except by small groups like the Kurds.  Where is the collective Islamist shock and condemnation of murder in the name of Islam?  Even more disturbing, where is the shock and condemnation by Muslims living in the U.S.?
Do you recall Americans up in arms over Irish bombers killing people in GB? Believers always claim that fanatics are not representative of the faith.

What I don't understand is why aren't the Muslims part of this fight?

Where are the Saudi troops? You know, the people of Saudi Arabia where 15 of the 19 hijackers were from on 9/11. Why aren't the people of Qatar part of this fight? You know, the people who are paying $200 BILLION on a soccer tournament, instead of on anti-terroism. Why are thousands of Syrian men pouring over the border instead of fighting?

If this truly is a world war, why aren't the Muslim countries taking in refugees and paying to fight these extremists with everything they have?
Doesn't Deb's pic today have a nice Phillip, too?

Google search has brought me here.. There are many negative comment on Samsung...
Samsung also has many positive part
Felicidades a Jordi Pizarro por este gran trabajo. Congrats since México City.

Yes, that's true some S Korean people regards buying as patriotic way, while as like everywhere world, Die-hard enthusiasts of Apple are exist, and usually they bluntly ignore them, or even mocking them, You have pointed 'Samsung is everywhere', Yes, the fan claims there's Samsung fabricated chips and LCDs on their iDevices, so people who disregards iDevices because it is foreign-originated is often being silly rather than smart in discussion.

Not small number of Korean recognize Samsung's presence in their country, and even they worry since Samsung's foothold on their own economy is simply too much big, and for often times, Samsung's lack of their morality in comparison the amount of their power in it's country.

I don't know how far extend the 'average Korean', but all of discussion is made fairly public, on mainstream media, blogs or discussion boards. You know, even Korean lives 21st century, too.

Complete and well said, Tone.

Remember that Iraq, as with most straight lines on the Middle Eastern map, was laid out by 19th century colonialists in the waning days of the Ottoman Empire.
I hate to push the button that says "blow up the world."  Maybe we can get smart enough to think of another way out.

In case anybody missed it, the world is about unthinkable and perpetual war. The  battle is to the strong. After defeating the Nazis, and after defeating the Soviets, we had peace in the world for a fair interval. I lived through all of that, and I have the wisdom of these history lessons on my side. I pray that peaceniks will not turn my grandchildren over to the vile. (I even hate to push the button here that says "submit.")

Just a couple of days ago the NYT published an article where ISIS fighters were defecting after Kurds started winning against them. The macho mentality that exist among many cultures, in particular Islamic Arab culture, can only be defeated with someone who is stronger and has a strong will.

America and all Western countries are stronger, but do they have the will to defeat ISIS, regardless of civilian population that get killed by just happening to be at the wrong place at the wrong time? That's what it will take to defeat ISIS militarily. If no such will exists, may as well help them create their murderous state and contain them.

The last time we crushed someone in war it was Germany and Japan in World War II.   Are we prepared to be that ruthless again?    Maybe we need to engage in this, with our allies. But this won't be a Rummy-lite war.
That'll be the day.

I believe a NATO military response with ground troops is inevitable.

But, it's goals must be well thought out in advance, and accomplishable.

And while the geographic area of the "caliphate" may be occupied, that is not the same as "defeating" or "crushing" ISIS (or ISIL or whatever acronym you prefer). As with Al-Quaeda, ISIS as a movement is spread in many locations, and cells will carry on without easily being crushed by force.

With seven billion humans on our planet, easy travel around the globe and widespread access to lethal weapons and targets, fundamentalist driven disasters have become a fact of human affairs. This includes both religious (right to lifers, ultra orthodox sects of Islam, Christianity, Hinduism, etc) and nonreligious (racists, nationalists, "pure" capitalists, etc) varieties.

To deal better with extremism, we need to develop a better understanding of biology of the human mind, and use that to make societies fit places for most people to fit into and attain fulfillment while being productive.

Until we can improve our strategies based on such knowledge, we are limited to recurrent bouts of conflict at the cost of many of our childrens' lives.

It should be a major crime for westerners to travel to Syria and train with ISIS.  If someone returns to their country of origin after such a visit they should face a very long prison sentence.  It is madness to try to monitor them.
i agree--the strong men of the middle east had these fanatics in check

Iran is already engaged there and they are the enemy of Saudi Arabia.

The situation regarding Assad has to be worked out before proceeding. Right now he looks better than the alternative, as does Saddam. Mubarak said, on the eve of Bush invading Iraq, that if you invade Iraq you will create a thousand Al Quaidas.

I think this problem doesn't go away until we draw the line around Salafist Wahabist ideology which means Saudi's become our enemy (never mind they are tightly woven to Neocons in the U.S. & Israel, especially Netanyahu).

There are no Shia/Iranian sleeper cells in the west. It is the wahabist Saudis that are funding fundamentalist madrassas breeding jihadist. It was the Wahabaist that worked to over throw most of the five Islamic legal schools that regulated islamic life into something reasonable and moderate. They over through that in favor of fundamentalism - which means following Mohammed's example literally, which is intrinsically terroristic, down to including genocide.

The short answer is to destroy the wahabist movement and restore the old Islamic legal schools of thought. The medium term solution is for legal scholars to rely upon the Koran for rendering law and abandon the hadith and the Sira. The long term is to convert them all to Buddhism, Atheism, Hinduism, Confucianism, Catholicism, or Mainline Protestantism, anything other than Islam or fundamentalist/evangelical Christianity.

All of that suggest that Saudi's are not our friends but our enemies.

Ultimately a successful war against ISIS leads to an "allied" occupation of the region that ISIS currently claims. Using Berlin post WWII as a model there would be zones controlled by the primary allies. And would those be?

NATO
Russia
Iran
Saudia Arabia

That's actually kinda plausible.

ISIS and Al Queda cannot be defeated militarily. These types of terrorist attacks do not have a military solution. Drone warfare could not deter these attacks. Using the military to attack Iraq in response to 911 was the biggest mistake we made and we are now seeing the long term consequences of our actions.

We need a new strategy. A response using our intelligence community can have some positive results. I'm not sure if negotiating with these people will ever work, but we won't be able to bomb them into submission.

If our politicians continue to politicize these attacks for partisan gain we are done for.

I don't know, Roger.  Crushing ISIS sounds good, but would these terrorist ideologues really lose their ability to carry out attacks if they lost their geographic stronghold?  I may not recall all of the details, but haven't other major post-9/11, pre-ISIS attacks (London, Madrid) been carried out without a particular home state for the terrorists to plan from?  I think that the best chance for the West to prevent (or at least minimize) these attacks is through intense intelligence work rather than re-intensifying the cycle of deployments that has had such a negative impact on service members and their families.  Not to mention what further unintended consequences might flow from renewing an American/NATO ground war in Iraq and pushing it into Syria.

Will you be contributing any children to combat units? Do you have any problem raising taxes to pay the latest Marshall Plan or do we put it on the national credit card? Do you think Muslim nations in the Middle East will take kindly to your neo-colonialist reorganization of their societies?

And you of course will support a large tax increase, focused on the most well-off, and the oil companies, to pay for this, along with a universal draft with no exemptions for the children of the elite. And we should start selling war bonds like we did during WWII so folks like you can put their money where their mouth is and show us just how invested you are in this war. When the bills doing all of those things are passed by the Republican Congress, then I'll take warmongers like yourself seriously.

Let NATO and Russia and whatever Arab allies will join - form a military cooperative to surround the ISIS territories and work their way in. It will require many boots on the ground.  Let the Russians go in where Assad still has control of his part of Syria while NATO takes the rest.  Have Arab speakers with every unit, such as Kurds with the US troops - so that when the ISIS chameleons try and slip away they can better be outed.  Turn them over to the Kurds when discovered.  Once Syria and Iraq are cleared of ISIS - we do a shared Marshall Plan and rebuild infrastructure such as bridges, electricity and water, schools. We return all the Syrians and Iraqi's whom have fled to their homeland.  This will build connections with moderate Islam, relieve western democracies from having to give welfare and housing to millions and teach radical/fundamentalist Islam that we crush them should they ever crawl out from their rocks again to inflict terrorism on western democracies.  Completely revisit our relationship with Saudi Arabia.  Jettison them as a partner if they do not completely overhaul their support of conservative Islam.  Such as women can work and vote and go to school.  Such as a Muslim can convert to Christianity or even deny God without harm coming to them.  And so much more of getting rid of the cancers that are in any and all fundamentalist religions (Christian, Jew, Muslim and Hindu) that make them think they are the chosen ones.

"Bush acted first and thought later, something no one can accuse Obama of doing." It is also true that Obama thinks first. The problem is he never acts - and this is coming from someone who twice voted for him.

olivia - exactly right.  Afghanistan was invaded and occupied with overwhelming force, in response to the 9/11 attack that was carried out by 19 people and plotted by al Qaeda, which at the time was bin Laden and accomplices who numbered how many?  A dozen?  A hundred?  Certainly not numbers that warranted massive military deployment.  The response was surely what bin Laden wanted, exceeding his wildest dreams with the Iraq invasion as a huge bonus.

paris was attacked by 8 people, yet cohen proposes sending massive armies to crush isis. gw bush demonstrated the folly of believing you can defeat terrorism with massive invasions. the problem in this case seems to be a conduit between syria, belgium, and france. i suggest france focus its efforts there, and we support them with intelligence gathering, as we continue to destroy isis leadership, supply routes, and plan effective special ops missions coordinating with the kurds as we have been doing. let's not take over a swath of territory as we did in iraq, only to find there is no one to govern it when we leave.
They throw word grenades to assist harmful people to toss physical hand grenades - thanks Coulter and Newt! Hot dangerous air balloons (buffoons) that place us all in danger.

How long should we wait? Should we wait until after the Sunday talk shows and the next round of Obama administration prevarication? Should we hold our fire until a French filmmaker is jailed?

Would Mr. Bruni like to post the transcript of Mr. Obama's declaration that his ISIS strategy is working (his claim on the morning of last evenings massacre)?

If so, I'll wait.
And so that makes everyone more safe?

"..which has been waging war against Islamic State for months, which is, of course one of the main reasons the attack occurred."

Victim blaming aside, if you truly believe ISIS & similar groups will simply "leave us alone" if we, them, you're not paying attention. They've openly expressed a determination to spread their religion throughout the world & inflict harm on those that don't or won't submit to its rules & laws. To that end, & for obvious reasons, the secular West is & will continue being Enemy #1 in their eyes. With or without military involvement in the Middle East.
